  "article_text": [
    "recall the freiheitssatz of magnus @xcite for one - relator groups :    [ the freiheitssatz ] let @xmath0 be a one - relator group where @xmath1 is cyclically reduced .",
    "if @xmath2 is a subset of @xmath3 which omits a generator occurring in @xmath1 , then the subgroup @xmath4 generated by @xmath2 is freely generated by @xmath2 .",
    "subgroups of a one - relator group of the form @xmath4 as in the freiheitssatz are called _",
    "magnus subgroups_. in @xcite , newman proved that the magnus subgroups of a one - relator group with torsion are malnormal , that is , if @xmath5 is a magnus subgroup and @xmath6 , then @xmath7 is trivial .",
    "bagherzadeh @xcite generalized newman s result in 1976 to ordinary one - relator groups and proved that magnus subgroups of one - relator groups are cyclonormal .",
    "he proved the following    [ b ] let @xmath5 be a magnus subgroup of a one - relator group @xmath8 .",
    "then @xmath5 is cyclonormal in @xmath9 , that is , if @xmath10 , then @xmath7 is cyclic .",
    "collins @xcite proved the following results about the intersection of magnus subgroups of a one - relator group @xmath9 .",
    "[ col1 ] let @xmath4 and @xmath11 be magnus subgroups of a one - relator group @xmath12 generated by subsets @xmath13 .",
    "then @xmath14 where @xmath15 is a free group of rank @xmath16 or @xmath17 .",
    "[ col2 ] let @xmath4 and @xmath11 be magnus subgroups of a one - relator group @xmath9 as in theorem [ col1 ] .",
    "for any @xmath18 , either @xmath19 is cyclic ( possibly trivial ) or @xmath20 .    here",
    "we use the notation @xmath21 to denote the intersection of two subgroups @xmath22 in the group @xmath9 , to distinguish it from the intersection in any other group containing them both .",
    "for example , in theorem [ col1 ] , if @xmath23 is the free group on @xmath3 , then @xmath24 ; the theorem tells us that this may differ from @xmath25 .    when these two intersections do differ , in other words when @xmath15 has rank 1 in theorem [ col1 ] , we say that the two magnus subgroups involved have _",
    "exceptional intersection_. the first author ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem e ) has shown that it is algorithmically decidable whether a given pair of magnus subgroups in a given one - relator group has exceptional intersection .",
    "a _ one - relator surface group _ is the quotient of the fundamental group of an orientable surface ( possibly noncompact , or with boundary ) by the normal closure of a single element .",
    "these groups were introduced in 1990 by hempel @xcite , and have subsequently been studied by bogopolski and sviridov @xcite and by the first author @xcite .    in this paper",
    "we generalize theorems [ b ] , [ col1 ] and [ col2 ] , as well as ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem e ) from one - relator groups to one - relator surface groups . with an appropriate definition of magnus subgroup , we prove the following .",
    "* theorem [ s ] * _ let @xmath9 be a one - relator surface group , and let @xmath5 be a magnus subgroup of @xmath9 .",
    "then @xmath5 is cyclonormal , that is , for any @xmath26 , @xmath7 is cyclic . _",
    "* theorem [ ss ] * _ the intersection @xmath27 of two compatible magnus subgroups @xmath28 and @xmath29 of the one - relator surface group @xmath9 is the free product of @xmath30 with a cyclic group .",
    "that is , @xmath31 . _",
    "( see  [ prelim ] for the definition of _ compatible _ magnus subgroups . )    * theorem [ alg ] * _ there is an algorithm which will decide , given a one - relator surface group and a pair of compatible magnus subgroups , whether or not the intersection is exceptional ( that is , @xmath32 in theorem [ ss ] ) and if so will give a generator for @xmath33 .",
    "_    * theorem [ sss ] * _ let @xmath9 be a one - relator surface group and let @xmath28 and @xmath29 be two magnus subgroups of @xmath9 .",
    "let @xmath18 , then @xmath34 is cyclic unless @xmath35 .",
    "_    theorems [ s ] , [ ss ] and [ sss ] appeared in the second author s thesis @xcite .",
    "we are grateful to the thesis exmainers , andrew duncan and nick gilbert , for useful comments .    in  [ prelim ] below we",
    "define our notion of magnus subgroup for one - relator surface groups and present some useful preliminary results .",
    "theorem [ s ] is proved in ",
    "[ cyclo ] , theorems [ ss ] and [ alg ] in  [ except ] , and finally theorem [ sss ] in  [ conj ] .",
    "in order to formulate appropriate generalizations of theorems about magnus subgroups of one - relator groups , we first need to choose a suitable definition of magnus subgroup for a one - relator surface group .",
    "a minimum requirement for a magnus subgroup is that it should satisfy an appropriate version of the freiheitssatz for one - relator surface groups - which turns out to be a somewhat delicate question ( see @xcite ) . for the purposes of exposition in the present paper we shall restrict our definition of magnus subgroup to a case where we know that a freiheitssatz holds .",
    "suppose that @xmath36 is a surface and @xmath37 is an essential separating simple closed curve on @xmath36 .",
    "then the surface group @xmath38 splits along @xmath37 as a free product with amalgamation : @xmath39 where @xmath40 and @xmath41 are the two components of @xmath36 cut along @xmath37 , and @xmath42 is the cyclic subgroup generated by @xmath37 .",
    "provided that @xmath43 is not conjugate into one of the factors @xmath44 , we say that @xmath45 and @xmath46 are _ magnus subgroups _ in the one - relator surface group @xmath47 .",
    "note that a magnus subgroup is generated by a subset of some standard generating set for the surface group @xmath38  for example @xmath48\\cdots [ a_k , b_k]=1\\>.\\ ] ]    ( freiheitssatz for one - relator surface groups ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition 3.10))[fhs ] if @xmath49 is a magnus subgroup in a one - relator surface group @xmath9 , then the inclusion map @xmath50 is injective ,    the separating curve @xmath37 in the definition is determined by the magnus subgroup only up to isotopy .",
    "we shall also refer to a pair of magnus subgroups @xmath28 and @xmath29 as _ compatible _ if the corresponding separating curves on @xmath36 can be chosen to be disjoint . in terms of generators",
    ", there exists a standard generating set such that both @xmath51 are generated by subsets of the chosen generating set for @xmath38 .",
    "* remark * let @xmath52\\cdots [ a_k , b_k]=r=1\\>\\ ] ] be a one - relator surface group , and @xmath53 a proper subset of the generating set of @xmath9 .",
    "then @xmath54 generates a subgroup @xmath5 of @xmath38 corresponding to the complement of a nonseparating simple closed curve in @xmath36 . in @xcite",
    "it is shown that the freiheitssatz does not in general hold for such subgroups : the natural map @xmath50 is not always injective .",
    "for this reason , we have excluded such subgroups from our definition of _",
    "magnus subgroup_.    moreover , it turns out that the results of this paper do not necessarily extend to groups of this form , even in situations where @xmath50 is injective .",
    "we shall give an example in  [ cyclo ] to illustrate this .",
    "in  [ cyclo ] below we will employ an idea first used by hempel ( * ? ? ?",
    "* lemma 2.1 , theorem 2.2 ) ( see also ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition 2.1 ) ) to express a one - relator surface group as an hnn extension of a one - relator group .",
    "here the notation @xmath55 denotes the algebraic intersection number of a pair of curves @xmath56 on the surface @xmath36 .",
    "[ trick ] let @xmath36 be a closed , connected , oriented surface of genus at least @xmath57 , and let @xmath37 be a closed curve in @xmath36",

    "@xmath68 ) is an hnn - extension of @xmath69 ( resp .",

    "each of @xmath73 , @xmath74 and @xmath75 consists of two circles , each of which represents ( a conjugate of ) @xmath76 .    in  [ except ] and  [ conj ] we will use a slight variation of this idea , which we will describe in the course of the proof of theorem [ ss ] .",
    "we shall also make extensive use of the fact that there is a lot of freedom in the choice of the curve @xmath58 .",
    "in particular , if @xmath77 is a punctured torus , then the restriction of the algebraic intersection map @xmath78 to @xmath79 gives a homomorphism @xmath80 with nonzero kernel ; we may choose a simple closed curve @xmath81 to represent a nonzero element of the kernel , and such a curve is automatically nonseparating .",
    "lemma [ sl ] below is an algebraic translation of this observation , applied to the case of the closed orientable surface @xmath36 of genus @xmath82 , with a standard generating set @xmath83 for @xmath67 , where @xmath84 is generated by @xmath85 .    if @xmath1 is an element of a free group @xmath23 with basis @xmath3 , and @xmath86 , we denote by @xmath87 the exponent - sum of @xmath88 in @xmath1 , in other words the image of @xmath1 under the homomorphism @xmath89 defined by @xmath90 , @xmath91 .",
    "[ sl ] let @xmath1 be an element of the free group @xmath92 .",
    "then there exists a basis @xmath93 of the free group @xmath94 , such that    \\(i ) @xmath95=[a_k , b_k]$ ] ; and    \\(ii ) as a reduced word in @xmath96 , @xmath1 has exponent sum zero in @xmath97 .",
    "[ s ] let @xmath9 be a one - relator surface group , and let @xmath5 be a magnus subgroup of @xmath9 .",
    "then @xmath5 is cyclonormal , that is , for any @xmath98 , @xmath7 is cyclic .    without loss of generality",
    ", we may assume that @xmath99\\cdots [ a_k , b_k]=r=1\\rangle\\ ] ] and that @xmath100 let @xmath6 be an element of @xmath9 .    by lemma [ sl ]",
    ", we may assume that @xmath101 that is , the exponent sum of @xmath102 in @xmath1 is zero .",
    "let @xmath58 denote the simple - closed curve on @xmath36 representing @xmath103 , such that @xmath104 .",
    "then hempel s trick ( proposition [ trick ] ) with this choice of @xmath58 expresses @xmath9 as an hnn - extension @xmath105 of a one - relator group @xmath106 , in such a way that @xmath3 and @xmath2 are isomorphic magnus subgroups of @xmath106 , with @xmath5 a free factor of @xmath3 and such that , in fact , @xmath106 is a one - relator product of @xmath5 and @xmath2 .",
    "the bass - serre tree for this hnn - extension has vertex - stabilizers the conjugates of @xmath106 and edge - stabilizers the conjugates of @xmath3 ( or the conjugates of @xmath2 ) .",
    "let @xmath107 be the bass - serre tree for this hnn - extension and suppose @xmath108 .",
    "then @xmath9 acts on @xmath107 and there exists a vertex @xmath109 such that @xmath110 @xmath111 moreover , @xmath3 and @xmath2 are the stabilisers of two edges of @xmath107 , which have @xmath109 as source and target respectively .    now @xmath112 stabilizes @xmath109 and @xmath113 stabilizes @xmath114 so that @xmath7 stabilizes both @xmath109 and @xmath114 and hence stabilizes the path @xmath115 in @xmath107 from @xmath109 to @xmath114 . here",
    "three different cases arise",
    ".    * case 1 . * if @xmath116 , then @xmath117 and the result follows from bagherzadeh s theorem [ b ] .",
    "* case 2 . *",
    "if the path @xmath115 is not coherently oriented , then there is an intermediate vertex @xmath118 of @xmath115 that is either the source of each incident edge of @xmath115 or the target of each incident edge of @xmath115 .",
    "we treat the latter case ( figure [ 13 ] ) ; the former is entirely analogous .",

    "the edge @xmath127 of @xmath115 incident at @xmath109 has target @xmath109 and so has stabilizer @xmath128 for some @xmath123 .",
    "now @xmath129 and @xmath106 is a one - relator product of the free groups @xmath5 and @xmath2 , so @xmath130 is cyclic by a result of brodski ( * ? ? ? * teorema 6(b ) ) .    in all cases we have shown that @xmath7 is cyclic .",
    "hence @xmath5 is cyclonormal in @xmath9 .",
    "below we give an example to show that theorem [ s ] does not extend to a subgroup @xmath5 of @xmath9 generated by @xmath131 of the @xmath132 generators of @xmath9 , even in cases where @xmath5 is free on those generators .",

    ", collins @xcite shows that @xmath137 .",
    "note also that @xmath138[a_2,b_2]=1\\rightarrow a_2^{-1}b_2a_2=b_2[a_1,b_1]$ ] , so that the nonabelian free subgroup @xmath139\\>$ ] of @xmath5 is identified in @xmath9 with the subgroup @xmath140 of @xmath141 .",
    "hence @xmath142 is not cyclic , so @xmath5 is not cyclonormal in @xmath9 .",
    "our aim in this section is to prove the analogue of the theorem [ col1 ] of collins for one - relator surface groups .",

    "the proof of theorem [ ss ] shows that magnus subgroups can have exceptional intersection only in very restricted circumstances - where @xmath198 in the notation of the proof .",
    "moreover , in that case it is equivalent to a pair of magnus subgroups in a one - relator group having exceptional intersection .",
    "we can use this to generate examples of exceptional intersections of magnus subgroups in one - relator surface groups .    * example * let @xmath9 be the one - relator surface group @xmath199[a_2,b_2]=a_1^{-2}b_1 ^ 4a_1 ^ 2a_2^{-2}b_2^{-3 } a_2 ^ 2a_1^{-2}b_1 ^ 2a_1 ^ 2a_2^{-2}b_2^{-3}a_2 ^ 2=1\\>.\\ ] ] if @xmath200 and @xmath201 , then the second relation is @xmath202 .",
    "collins @xcite shows that @xmath203 is a consequence of that relation . if @xmath204 and @xmath205 , then @xmath206 and @xmath207 .",
    "hence @xmath28 and @xmath29 have exceptional intersection in @xmath9 .",
    "the strong restrictions on exceptional intersection that arise in the proof of theorem [ ss ] also give rise to a proof of theorem [ alg ] , which we sketch below    [ alg ] there is an algorithm which will decide , given a one - relator surface group @xmath9 and two magnus subgroups @xmath51 , whether or not @xmath28 and @xmath29 have exceptional intersection in @xmath9 . if the intersection is exceptional , the algorithm will provide a generator for the free factor @xmath33 in the statement of theorem [ ss ] .    _ sketch proof . _",
    "the theorem is proved by noting that each step in the proof of theorem [ ss ] can be carried out algorithmically .",
    "we may assume that the one - relator surface group has the form @xmath208\\cdots[a_k , b_k]=r=1\\>,\\ ] ] where @xmath1 is a word in the generators .",
    "the first step is a basis - change in the free group @xmath209 to allow us to assume that @xmath210 .",
    "the euclidean algorithm transforms the vector @xmath211 to a vector of the form @xmath212 using integer elementary column operations , which can be lifted to nielsen operations on @xmath209 in the standard way .",
    "thus the basis - change operation of lemma [ sl ] can be performed algorithmically , and so we may assume without further ado that @xmath210 , and similarly that @xmath213 .",
    "the rewrites @xmath214 in the proof of theorem [ ss ] are entirely mechanical processes , as is the choice of a suitable cyclic conjugate in each case .",
    "thus the non - negative integers @xmath215 occurring in the proof can be algorithmically computed . should either be strictly positive , then we can stop , declaring the intersection to be non - exceptional .",
    "hence we may assume that @xmath216 , so that ( up to conjugation ) , @xmath198 in the notation of the proof of theorem [ ss ] . now @xmath188 and @xmath54 are free groups of infinite rank , so in order to handle this situation algorithmically we must replace them by appropriate finite rank free groups . in practice , one can algorithmically generate finite sets @xmath217 that are subsets of bases of @xmath218 respectively , and such that @xmath1 can be expressed ( up to conjugacy ) as a word in @xmath219 .",
    "now apply the algorithm of ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem e ) to the one - relator group @xmath220 to decide whether or not the intersection is exceptional .",
    "if so , the algorithm provides a generator @xmath221 for the exceptional free factor , in terms of our chosen basis for @xmath172 together with @xmath222 .",
    "finally , we translate @xmath221 into a word in the original generators @xmath223 of @xmath9 to complete the algorithm .",
    "in this section we prove the analogue of theorem [ col2 ] .          with the same notation as in the proof of theorem [ ss ] , we express @xmath9 as an hnn extension of a one - relator group @xmath163 , with stable letter @xmath102 and associated subgroups @xmath233 , @xmath234 , where @xmath160 is generated by @xmath235 together with @xmath155 for @xmath236 , for some @xmath237 . in particular @xmath167 .      now @xmath9 acts on the bass - serre tree @xmath107 arising from this hnn description .",
    "the stabilizers of the vertices are conjugates of @xmath240 and the stabilizers of the edges are conjugates of @xmath233 ( and hence also of @xmath234 ) .",
    "let @xmath120 be a vertex of @xmath107 such that @xmath241 , and let @xmath242 be two edges of @xmath107 incident at @xmath120 such that @xmath243 and @xmath244",
    ".    now suppose that @xmath245",
    ". then @xmath246 stabilises the ( nonempty ) geodesic path @xmath115 in @xmath107 from @xmath120 to @xmath247 .",
    "moreover , since @xmath248 , this path has even length and contains the same number of forward - pointing and backward - pointing edges . in particular , there is an intermediate vertex @xmath109 in @xmath115 which is either the source of both the incident edges of @xmath115 or the target of both the incident edges of @xmath115 .",
    "we assume the latter .",
    "( the analysis of the former case is analogous . )    if @xmath249 , then the stabilisers of the edges of @xmath115 incident at @xmath109 have the form @xmath250 and @xmath251 for some @xmath252 with @xmath253 . by bagherzadeh s theorem [ b ] , @xmath254 is cyclic , and hence the stabiliser of @xmath115 is cyclic , and the result follows .",
    "thus we are reduced to the case where @xmath255 .",
    "but in that case @xmath28 and @xmath158 are magnus subgroups of the one - relator group @xmath169 , and @xmath256 which is cyclic by collins theorem [ col2 ] , unless @xmath257    99 g.h .",

    "* 105 * , 52 - 74 ( 1931 ) .",
    "newman , _ some results on one - relator groups _ , bull .",
    "* 74 * , 568 - 571 ( 1968 ) .",
    "ann . , * 78 * , 385 - 397 ( 1918 ) . m.s .",
    "one - relator quotients of surface groups _ , phd thesis , heriot - watt university , uk ( 2007 ) ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> a one - relator surface group is the quotient of an orientable surface group by the normal closure of a single relator . </S>",
    "<S> a magnus subgroup is the fundamental group of a suitable incompressible sub - surface . </S>",
    "<S> a number of results are proved about the intersections of such subgroups and their conjugates , analogous to results of bagherzadeh , brodski and collins in classical one - relator group theory . </S>"
  ]
}
